sectionTitle: K.4: Fourteen Gunasthän - Stages of Spiritual Development

tabs.caption: Foundational concepts of the Gunasthans, the soul's journey from impurity to liberation.

items.content: A Gunasthän (literally'stage of virtue') represents a specific psychical condition or spiritual stage of a soul in its journey towards liberation (Moksha). It is a measure on a spiritual yardstick, determined by the state of the soul's beliefs, conduct, and the influence of karmic matter. The journey progresses from a state of complete wrong belief (Mithyātva) to the state of a liberated soul (Paramātmā). This progression is influenced by the fruition (Uday), suppression (Upasham), and perishing (Kshayopasham) of karmas.

The soul's journey through the Gunasthans is not a simple, linear ascent. A soul can move up and down the stages based on its internal state and karmic load. There are three primary states of the soul corresponding to these stages:
  • Bahirātmā (Extrovert Soul): Stages 1-3. The soul is engrossed in external objects and activities, identifying itself with the body and worldly possessions.
  • Antarātmā (Introvert Soul): Stages 4-12. The soul turns inward, concerned with its own spiritual welfare and purification. It differentiates itself from the body and karma.
  • Paramātmā (Perfect Soul): Stages 13-14. The soul attains Godhood, becoming an omniscient, perfect being, free from all defiling karmas.

Gunasthans are directly tied to karma bondage. The primary karma influencing these stages is Mohaniya (Deluding) Karma, which has two main sub-types:
1. Darshan Mohaniya: Faith-deluding karma, which causes wrong belief (Mithyātva).
2. Chāritra Mohaniya: Conduct-deluding karma, which obstructs right conduct and gives rise to passions (Kashāy).
Progress through the Gunasthans involves systematically suppressing or eradicating these karmas.

The spiritual state is also defined by the presence or absence of the five causes of karmic influx (Āsrav). Progressing to higher Gunasthans requires eliminating these causes one by one:
1. Mithyātva (Wrong Faith)
2. Avirati (Vowlessness / Indiscipline)
3. Pramād (Negligence / Laziness)
4. Kashāy (Passions: Anger, Pride, Deceit, Greed)
5. Yoga (Activities of mind, body, and speech)

nodes.description: The Fourteen Stages of Spiritual Development
Wrong Faith: The soul has a perverse attitude towards truth.
Lingering Taste of True Faith: A brief, transitory stage while falling from a higher state.
Mixed Faith: A state of indifference, mixing belief and non-belief.
Right Faith without Vows: The soul has right faith but lacks the self-control to take vows.
Partial Renunciation: A layman (Shrāvak) who has taken minor vows (Anu-vratas).
Full Renunciation with Less Awareness: An ascetic (Sādhu) who has taken major vows but is still prone to negligence (Pramād).
Renunciation with Full Awareness: An ascetic free from negligence (Pramād).
Meditative State: Unprecedented spiritual purification and thoughts occur.
Advanced Meditative State: Further purification where passions are nearly eliminated.
Subtle Greed: Only a subtle form of greed remains as a passion.
Suppressed Passions: All passions are suppressed, but not yet eradicated. (Only on Upasham Shreni).
Passionless Stage: All deluding (Mohaniya) karmas are completely eradicated. (Only on Kshapak Shreni).
Active Omniscience: The soul is an omniscient being (Kevali) with activities (Yoga) of mind, body, and speech. This is an Arihant.
Inactive Omniscience: All activities cease. This is the final, momentary stage before attaining Moksha (liberation).

tabs.caption: An in-depth look at each Gunasthan, its characteristics, and the karmas involved.

items.content: This is the lowest stage where the soul, due to the manifestation of Mithyātva Mohaniya Karma, has a perverse attitude towards truth. All five causes of Āsrav are present. A soul can be in this stage from eternity. From here, a soul rises directly to the 4th stage.

items.header: 2. Sāsvādan Samyag-drashti Gunasthān (Lingering Taste of True Faith)
items.content: A very brief, transitory stage (max 6 Āvalikā) experienced only when a soul is falling from the 4th stage (or higher). The soul temporarily loses right faith but retains a memory or'taste' of it before falling back to the 1st stage. This happens if Anantānu-bandhi Kashāy becomes operative before Mithyātva Mohaniya Karma.

A transitory stage (less than 48 minutes) of indifference, a mix of belief and non-belief. This occurs when falling from the 4th stage due to the re-emergence of Mishra Mohaniya Karma. From here, the soul can fall to the 1st stage or rise back to the 4th.

items.header: 4. Avirat Samyag-drashti Gunasthān (Right Faith without Vows)
items.content: The soul attains Right Faith (Samyaktva) for the first time by suppressing the Darshan Saptak (3 Darshan Mohaniya + 4 Anantānu-bandhi Kashāy). However, due to remaining conduct-deluding karmas, it cannot take any vows (Avirati). This is the first stage of being an Antarātmā.

The stage of a layman (Shrāvak) who adopts partial vows (Anu-vratas). This is achieved by suppressing or eradicating the four types of Apratyākhyāni Kashāy. This is the highest stage possible for a householder.

items.header: 6. Pramatta-Sanyat Gunasthän (Full Renunciation with Less Awareness)
items.content: The stage of an ascetic (Sādhu) who has taken the five great vows (Mahā-vratas) but is still susceptible to Pramād (negligence, laziness). This is achieved by overcoming the four types of Pratyākhyāni Kashāy.

An ascetic who is completely free from Pramād (negligence). The soul is constantly vigilant and absorbed in spiritual pursuits. This stage is the gateway to the two higher spiritual ladders (Shrenis).

items.header: 8. Apurva-karan Gunasthän (Meditative State with Unprecedented Purity)
items.content: The soul experiences Apurva (unprecedented) purity and thoughts. It begins the rapid shedding of karmas. This is the first step on either the Upasham or Kshapak Shreni.
Further spiritual advancement where passions, except for subtle greed, are eliminated. The thought processes of all souls in this stage at a particular time are identical.
Only the slightest, most subtle form of greed (Sanjvalan Lobh) remains from the conduct-deluding karma. All other passions have been quelled.

This stage is only reached via the Upasham Shreni (ladder of suppression). All Mohaniya karma, including subtle greed, is completely suppressed but not destroyed. Like dirt settling in water, it will inevitably re-emerge, causing the soul to fall to a lower stage.

This stage is only reached via the Kshapak Shreni (ladder of destruction). All 28 types of Mohaniya Karma are completely and permanently eradicated (Kshina). The soul is now free of passions and delusion. From here, there is no falling back.

The stage of a Keval-jnāni (Omniscient Being), also known as an Arihant or Jina. The four Ghāti (destructive) karmas are destroyed. The soul possesses perfect knowledge and perception but still has a body and exhibits Yoga (activities of mind, speech, and body). This is the state of a Paramātmā.

The final, momentary stage before liberation. The Kevali ceases all Yoga (activities) in a process called Shaileshi-karan. The soul remains in this state for the time it takes to utter five short vowels, then sheds the remaining Aghāti karmas and the physical body to achieve Moksha.

tabData.title: Gunasthan Concepts
tabData.description: Fundamental terms for understanding the stages of spiritual development.

cards.back: A stage of spiritual development on the path to liberation, defined by the soul's purity and karmic state.
Wrong faith; a perverse attitude towards truth. The defining characteristic of the 1st Gunasthan.
Deluding Karma. The primary karma that obstructs right faith and right conduct, governing the Gunasthans.
A group of 7 karmas (3 faith-deluding + 4 Anantānu-bandhi passions) whose suppression allows the soul to reach the 4th Gunasthan.
'Extrovert' Soul (Stages 1-3). A soul focused on external objects and identifying with the body.
'Introvert' Soul (Stages 4-12). A soul focused on its own spiritual purification.
'Perfect' Soul (Stages 13-14). A liberated or near-liberated soul; a God.
The'Ladder of Suppression'. A spiritual ascent to the 11th stage where karmas are suppressed, not destroyed. The soul will inevitably fall from this ladder.
The'Ladder of Destruction'. A spiritual ascent to the 12th stage where deluding karmas are permanently destroyed, ensuring liberation.
13th Gunasthan. An'Active Omniscient Being' (Arihant) who still has activities of mind, body, and speech.
14th Gunasthan. An'Inactive Omniscient Being' who has ceased all activities just before attaining Moksha.
A state of absolute motionlessness achieved in the 14th Gunasthan, where all physical, vocal, and mental activities stop.
